thread.title: AWB worried Iraq payments ‘too direct’ | The Australian
thread.title_full: AWB worried Iraq payments ‘too direct’ | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: AWB worried Iraq payments ‘too direct’ | The Australian
text:
Australian Securities and Investments Commission barrister Norman O’Bryan has told a Victorian Supreme Court civil trial of former AWB chairman Trevor Flugge and senior executive Peter Geary that in mid 2000 Mr Geary received an email from another executive, Tim Snowball, discussing Iraq’s refusal to accept two shipments of wheat they maintained were tainted with E. coli, despite United Nations tests indicating otherwise.
“Iraq is in total control here,” Mr Snowball wrote to Mr Geary.
“The UN knows there is no quality issue and that Iraq is only playing games to force the removal of sanctions.
“AWB is the only supplier bending to Iraq’s needs.”
Mr O’Bryan told Justice Ross Robson this was “one of the clearest warning bells that could be rung” about AWB’s knowledge of what its dealings with Iraq entailed.
The UN passed successive resolutions prohibiting the transfer of funds or other economic resources to the government of Iraq, following Hussein’s invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
ASIC is accusing Mr Geary of breaching his duties as an executive 13 times in the subsequent oil for food scandal that saw AWB pay Iraq more than $300 million in kickbacks disguised as trucking and after-sale service fees between 1999 and the US-led invasion of the country in 2003.
Mr Flugge is accused of four breaches, each of which carries a maxim penalty of $200,000.
Mr O’Bryan told the court AWB executives were concerned their first “trucking fee” payment, made to the Jordanian bank account of intermediary Iraqi company Alia in 1999 was “too direct”.
In an internal AWB email, AWB Middle East and Africa sales manager Mark Emons described two phone conversations he had the previous night with Iraqi Grain Board head Zuhair Daoud.
“On the trucking fee, I’m still having some problems with him,” Mr Emons wrote to fellow AWB executive Michael Watson.
“He understands we can’t pay Iraq direct.”
Mr Emons then proposed the first payment be made via the Jordanian Alia account.
“I know this is a little to direct, (sic) but he assures me that it is a one-off,” Mr Emons wrote.
He told Mr Watson they would discuss future payment methods with the IGB head in person during an imminent visit to Iraq.
The payment of USD $453,600 was made to the nominated Alia account within a few days.
Mr O’Bryan told the court that during the 1999-2000 season, AWB sold a record 2.4 million tonnes of wheat to Iraq, more than double the pre-1990 annual average.
Lawyers for Mr Flugge and Mr Geary are yet to give their opening statements in the trial, which is expected to last 10 weeks.
Both men were absent from court today, having attended on Monday when the case opened.
